results.title: Beyond the rift wall
results.creator_credit: Charlotte Gobeil, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and Canadian International Development Agency
results.brief_description: A film about a group of farmers and their wives who went to live and work among the Tanzanians, training them in Canadian methods of grain growing and production. It examines the cultural effects of this exchange both on the Canadians, who found themselves isolated by geography and language, and on the Tanzanians who were exposed to Canadian work habits and technology.

results.title: Beyond kicks
results.creator_credit: Gary Toole, George Pearson, Michael McKennirey and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This is about a group of young volunteers, the Free Youth Clinic, who run a ‘crisis bus’ to rescue young people experiencing bad drug trips, usually LSD. They pull up whenever the need arises and try to talk the person down. If the patient needs further medical aid, they know where to obtain it. The film shows some of the patients being interviewed after their rescue.

results.title: Beyond Everest (1980). Beyond Everest: the ongoing climb of Sherpa Hillary (2000)
results.creator_credit: Michael Dillon, Dick Smith Adventure and Michael Dillon Film Enterprises
results.brief_description: Conquering the mountain of Everest was not Sir Edmund Hillary’s only achievement in Nepal. Through a philanthropic enterprise he continued to fund development projects for the Nepalese people - projects that the people themselves requested. His legacy will live on through the children of Nepal attending one of the some 30 schools that his “Himalayan Trust” built since 1961 - in many cases by his own hands. This DVD contains two documentaries - one made in 1980 is about Sir Edmund at sixty years of age and the other made in 2000 continues the subject matter of his philanthropic work - the DVD release commemorates the 50th Anniversary of Sir Edmund Hillary’s ascent of Mount Everest.

results.title: Between two wars: sunshine and eclipse (1927-1934)
results.creator_credit: William Weintraub, Nicholas Balla and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Confident, prosperous Canada, expanding in all directions; then the stock market crash of 1929, its sequel the Great Depression, and a nation staggering with poverty and unemployment. But with it all, an optimistic outlook: bargains by mail order; extremes in women’s fashions; political see-sawing; hockey broadcasts by a very youthful Foster Hewitt; the word “quintuplets” in every headline.
results.creator_credit_for_label: William Weintraub, Nicholas Balla and National Film Board of Canada
results.description: Confident, prosperous Canada, expanding in all directions; then the stock market crash of 1929, its sequel the Great Depression, and a nation staggering with poverty and unemployment. results.title: Shakespeare
results.creator_credit: Roger Parsons, BBC and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Changing stages”.
Theatre, film director and BBC Governor, Richard Eyre was invited to write and present a series for the BBC about the history of theatre in the 20th century. He chose to write the book first and base his TV series on that book (Changing stages). This is that series - consisting of six episodes exploring the very existence of theatre in today’s multi-media techno world. The question is asked whether the art of “live” performance can survive, an art which relies on the present tense, the here and now as it is being performed, where illusion can become reality and the audience can use its imagination and interaction with the performers on stage. “All aspects of our life are recorded…theatre is the most human of all art forms” (Richard Eyre). The first episode begins with William Shakespeare - his plays, his influence not only throughout Britain but world-wide, the theatres in which his plays have been performed over the centuries, and the many and varied adaptations of his writings on stage and in film, including excerpts from the films “Shakespeare in love” and “Romeo and Juliet” and theatre productions “Othello” (Royal Shakespeare Company, 1999) and “Macbeth” (1979), proving Shakespeare’s longevity and adaptability to modern times. Richard Eyre is passionate about the subject of theatre and through his enthusiasm and entertaining anecdotes, excerpts, stills, archival footage and interviews with renowned actors, directors and playwrights including Ian McKellen, Judi Dench, Baz Luhrmann, Tom Stoppard, Arthur Miller, Peter Brook, Peter Hall, Sir John Gielgud, Sir Laurence Olivier, among others, the viewer is given an insight and an appreciation of Britain’s national icon and best-known playwright. Contains some b&w footage. Written and presented by Richard Eyre. For more information see www.pbs.org/wnet/changingstages.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Roger Parsons, BBC and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)

results.title: Ireland
results.creator_credit: Mary Downes, BBC and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Changing stages”.
Second episode in the six-part series “Changing stages”, written and presented by Richard Eyre, about the history of theatre in the 20th century. This program focuses on Ireland and some of the Irish playwrights who gave birth to a new kind of theatre, one that had more substance than the 19th century Victorian melodrama and moralising society plays which were being performed in Britain, most significantly, at a time when Ireland was fighting for independence from British empirical connections. Richard Eyre discusses in great detail the influences and historical background of several Irish playwrights including William Butler Yeats, George Bernard Shaw, Oscar Wilde, Sean O’Casey, and J.M. Synge and the part these individuals played in the establishment of a national theatre and a national identity for Ireland. Yeats, Shaw and Wilde were all born in Dublin around the same time, but Shaw and Wilde very early on exiled themselves to England to make their fame and fortune through satirising the English high society. In contrast, against a background of political turmoil and tension, Yeats, in collaboration with Lady Augusta Gregory, conceived The Abbey Theatre which was to become Ireland’s national theatre and a stage for the works of Sean O’Casey and J.M. Synge, both playwrights who shared the belief that plays could be about contemporary events and the reality of people’s lives. Contains excerpts from film adaptations and theatrical performances including “The Importance of being Ernest” (Wilde), “The Playboy of the western world” (Synge), “Juno and the paycock” (O’Casey), “Pygmalion” (Shaw), “The Plough and the stars” (O’Casey), “Mrs Warren’s profession” (Shaw) and interviews and conversations with actors and playwrights including Stephen Rea, Liam Neeson, Fiona Shaw, Alan Bennett, Tom Stoppard, Peter Gill, Edna O’Brien and David Hare. Also uses b&w archival footage, stills, and beautiful images of the Irish landscape and seascape. For more information see www.pbs.org/wnet/changingstages.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mary Downes, BBC and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)

results.title: Beyond the clouds = Par-dela les nuages
results.creator_credit: Michelangelo Antonioni, Philippe Carcassonne, Stephen Tchal Gadjieff, Cecchi Gori Group, Cine B, France 3 Cinema, Road Movies Zweite Produktionen and Sunshine
results.brief_description: This was Antonioni’s return to filmmaking after suffering a stroke in 1985. He presents 4 vignettes linked thematically by notions of desire, as well as a fictional director in search of a story (portrayed by John Malkovich). In the first story two beautiful lovers, Silvano and Carmen (Kim Rossi Stuart and Ines Sastre) are unable to consummate their love because of his pursuit of perfection. In the second story John Malkovich’s character meets a woman (Sophie Marceau) who confesses to killing her father. The third story involves a man (Peter Weller) who must decide between his wife (Fanny Ardant) and his lover (Chiara Caselli). In the final story a man (Vincent Perez) becomes obsessed with a woman (Irene Jacob) who is “satisfied” with life and is about to enter a convent. Screen legends Jeanne Moreau and Marcello Mastroianni make a brief appearance and have an overall involvement to the story rather than being directly involved with any of the vignettes. In French, Italian and English with English subtitles. Co-directed by Wim Wenders.

results.title: Between Brecht and Beckett
results.creator_credit: Jamie Muir, BBC and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Changing stages”.
Fifth episode in the six-part series “Changing stages”, written and presented by Richard Eyre, about the history of theatre in the 20th century. The aftermath of WW II influenced the direction of theatre and allowed a whole new generation of playwrights the freedom to express their anger, their political allegiance, social realism and an attitude that you could do or say what you want on stage - theatre became the instrument of social change. However, it was first German dramatist and poet, Bertolt Brecht (1898-1956), then Irish born Samuel Beckett (1906-1989) who inspired the 1960s and 70s generation of playwrights. Brecht, a communist, was known as a “theorist about theatre” who challenged the traditional values of theatre creating experimental and revolutionary works around his theory of alienation, promoting a style of acting and staging that created a distancing effect. Samuel Beckett was the man of evocative language, his plays often shrouded in despair and bleakness, combined with a lacing of caustic humor and left-wing politics. Richard Eyre presents indepth biographical backgrounds of each of these playwrights, including excerpts from their plays “The Resistible rise of Arturo Ui” and “Galileo” (Brecht), and “Waiting for Godot” (Beckett). Also features playwrights Edward Bond, Harold Pinter, Caryl Churchill, David Hare, Alan Bennett, Tom Stoppard and others along with film clips, excerpts and interviews. In addition, the program provides an historical overview of Britain during the 60s and 70s, the political and sexual freedom and the social mores of a society in the throes of a revolution - in fact, the whole world seemed to be in a state of protest in 1968. Follows through to the 1970s, to 1979 and the beginning of Thatcherism in Britain. Contains interviews with actors, playwrights and directors including John McGrath, Peter Brook, Tony Kushner, Billie Whitelaw. Some footage in b&w. For more information see www.pbs.org/wnet/changingstages.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jamie Muir, BBC and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Changing stages”.
Fifth episode in the six-part series “Changing stages”, written and presented by Richard Eyre, about the history of theatre in the 20th century. The aftermath of WW II influenced the direction of theatre and allowed a whole new generation of playwrights the freedom to express their anger, their political allegiance, social realism and an attitude that you could do or say what you want on stage - theatre became the instrument of social change. However, it was first German dramatist and poet, Bertolt Brecht (1898-1956), then Irish born Samuel Beckett (1906-1989) who inspired the 1960s and 70s generation of playwrights. Brecht, a communist, was known as a “theorist about theatre” who challenged the traditional values of theatre creating experimental and revolutionary works around his theory of alienation, promoting a style of acting and staging that created a distancing effect. Samuel Beckett was the man of evocative language, his plays often shrouded in despair and bleakness, combined with a lacing of caustic humor and left-wing politics. Richard Eyre presents indepth biographical backgrounds of each of these playwrights, including excerpts from their plays “The Resistible rise of Arturo Ui” and “Galileo” (Brecht), and “Waiting for Godot” (Beckett). Also features playwrights Edward Bond, Harold Pinter, Caryl Churchill, David Hare, Alan Bennett, Tom Stoppard and others along with film clips, excerpts and interviews. In addition, the program provides an historical overview of Britain during the 60s and 70s, the political and sexual freedom and the social mores of a society in the throes of a revolution - in fact, the whole world seemed to be in a state of protest in 1968. Follows through to the 1970s, to 1979 and the beginning of Thatcherism in Britain. Contains interviews with actors, playwrights and directors including John McGrath, Peter Brook, Tony Kushner, Billie Whitelaw. Some footage in b&w. For more information see www.pbs.org/wnet/changingstages.

results.title: The Spiny Ant-eater
results.creator_credit: Arthur Hansen and Australian Instructional Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Wild Life”.
Sequence of shots of the Spiny Ant-Easter digging into the ground. The differences between it and European porcupines are explained as well as the unique characteristics of this strange Australian mammal.
